Naturally, QCs can do it on conventional cypher-coded text encrypted with P+P keys. What they could only rarely crack is content encrypted with true code generated with an auto-optimizing system using a OTP-like key protocol. For example, if content is not converted with a character-byte level cypher and not encrypted with a maths-based P+P key scheme, then Shor's algorithm & QCs would be useless. Yes, true code & a purely logical OTP-like key protocol can be truly uncrackable. It would be like trying to crack ancient Egyptian heiroglyphics without the Rosetta Stone, but much harder. Why? Optimal true coding of a natural language (supporting graphics, etc.) would seem as random as cosmic noise. Quantum computers do not have a parctical use *today. We are far from theoretical when it comes to quantum computers, but we are way, way further away from practical. It's unlikely that someone will ever get hacked by a quantum computer, *more unlikely than a quantum computer having a widespread practical use at some point. Still, we could be decades, if not a century or two from that.

The problem I have with quantum computers is that anyone who has interest, either scientific or investive/financial, is talking about them as if they are a thing already, that you can use today. This kind of computing, alongside "classical" computing today with which we can already encrypt and decrypt and have many uses for them, is too prevalent today that no other kind of computing is even considered or talked about. Going from transistors to something like quantum mechanics for computing is a major *leap*, but we humans advance best in steps; the scientific method is a long way round, and there are not shortcuts other than luck/accident, but the jump to quantum mechanics?

Sure, quantum computers need to be proven viable, and I understand that this is it, but talking about it like it's already here, possible, viable? It's dangerous and it will draw in misguided investments from people convinced by the scientific community having some stake or interest in quantum computing that this is a good investment purely by the fact that scienctists are pursuing it, so it must be viable.

I'm not saying we should stop pursuing quantum computing; there is more at stake in this pursuit other than getting a faster PC. What I'm saying is that we need to take a step back and pursue advancements in computing in a different field, using ideas less fantastical than quantum computing.

Only understood so much of it. Here's my "tldr;". So basically, encryption involves trying to find the factors of a very large number, but nobody has found a computationally efficient way to do that beyond randomly guessing factors. Shor's Algorithm makes a guess as well, but it's much more efficient under the right circumstances. It's been proven that you can take any two numbers that do not have common prime factors, and if you multiply them by themselves enough times they will nearly converge by being close by 1. Rearranging all that a bit with equations and you can define both variables as one variable called "P", which is the number of times each of these factors would have to multiply themselves by to equal eachother (plus 1). Shor's algorithm tries to find P, and with that it can factor any number. The algorithm still isn't that useful for regular computers, but it works really well for Quantum computers. Quantum computers work with probabilities because quantum mechanics is weird. Basically, because of the probabilistic nature of quantum computers when you input the number and algorithm the incorrect answers cancel each other out, leaving you with P, and the ability to factor the number.

This can be used against asymmetric encryption, but not symmetric encryption, which is what most data uses. Symmetric encryption takes a random string of letters and numbers, and uses that string to mash up the data in specific ways that you can't undo without knowing what the string is. No factoring is involved, and you can't use Shor's algorithm. However, getting your secret string to someone you trust usually DOES include asymmetric encryption. But if the quantum attacker missed the key exchange, you can't break in by doing this.

It is false that a quantum computer will always be able to break any encryption method.
When the encryption key is as large as the encrypted message it is impossible to break.
Simply because you would never know if you were successful without knowing ahead of time exactly what the message is...in which case you don't need to de-crypt anything.
Any de-crypted page of words that you think is the solution (because the page makes sense) is just as likely to be the solution as any other page of words that makes sense.
This is the same method as what was called a "one time pad".
But this is not claiming that a quantum computer would be useless...it could overcome current popular encryption methods....but once it is known that quantum computers are routinely breaking these methods.....people would not have to spend a lot to create "quantum secure" files.

This is why I encrypt using the alphabet, instead of numbers. I know you can't exactly factor letters, but it does allow for far more permutations. To determine how many permutations there are in a string of values, you multiply the number of digits by how many things each digit can be. With numbers you have ten options per digit. It can be any number from zero through nine. With letters on the other hand, you have 52 options per digit. It can be any letter from A to Z, then double for upper and lower case. A two digit number has 100 permutations, whereas a two letter case sensitive word has 2704 options.

Why does information pertaining to that period survive? It's clear that for arbitrary p, g^(1/p) won't produce the fixed remainder r mod N and so can't be a component of the superposed sum: for integral p, the exponent will be fractional and the problem is no longer well-defined over the integers. And if we were to expand to the reals, we can no longer bank on (1/p)'s uniqueness within the superposition as non-periodic with respect to p.

So I've stumbled across this video randomly, but I think I understand the basic concept of quantum physics, but I'm gonna give my version here so if it's wrong I can be corrected: Quantum physics is all about the idea that things can be in multiple usually mutually exclusive states at the same time, until they are observed, at which point they become only one state. So based off of that, I'm guessing the idea of a quantum computer is that instead of just being 1s and 0s, it can be a 1, 0, or both a 1 and 0 at the same time. Last thing I think I get is a superposition is when something is in 2 of these mutually exclusive states at the same time.

So with that all out of the way, the only thing I don't understand at all is why superpositions are necessary to perform this algorithm quickly enough. You said that multiple potential answers would be output from one input, and that 'negative interference' will cause the incorrect ones to gradually cancel out until there's one left - I assume what is meant by this is that there will be multiple possible answers to begin with because there are unknowns that we can think of like unobserved particles in both states at once, but as we find out what these unknowns are or 'observe' them we find contradicting information that means some of the answers can't be true and they assume one state or another. The sine wave you used in your example actually really helped me there, because I make electronic music, and that analogy helped me put this principle into a context I understand - the principle I think being that with enough 'samples' (possibilities) the 'phase cancellation' (contradicting facts) will average out the waveform at the correct 'amplitude' (factor to break encryption).

What I don't get is how that can't be done already by just storing all the possible outcomes and checking if they make sense without using superpositions, or is every possibility 'checked' at once all at the same time in the same time it would take to check just one without superpositions? Do superpositions allow quantum computers to actually multitask rather than simply do one thing at a time but swap out the thing you are doing each time really fast to give the illusion of multitasking like normal computers do, or am I not getting this?

Ok well switching to IPV6 is gonna cause a lot of cybersecurity problems as well. This is what happens when, by accomadating the issue of old standards that didn't expect such a rapid growth of technological use, you fundamentally eliminate certain functionalities of the old standard that provided avenues for securing networks. This is relevant because it identifies a theme, as new quantum computing technology, or technology in general advances, we eliminate traditional options for ensuring security. To simplify, security is ensured via looking at the fundamental functionality of systems in place. The easiest explanation being encryption, as while it technically can be cracked, it works so effectively because we know that with current systems, it will take an amount of time to solve that is longer than the issue will be relevant. As this video shows however, due to the fundamentally different nature of quantum computing, traditional encryption is rendered useless by the fact that the amount of time to crack encryption with quantum computers is no longer too long to be viable. That is the natural progression of our technology, as when we reach the fastest version of our current architectures, we will switch to that which is functionally different, rendering certain security measures obsolete.

9:50 - "we can't just measure this super position to get the answer, if we did we'd get a random element of the super position as output, like our-guess-squared is +5 than a multiple of N, which is no better than randomly guessing powers"

Hol'dup - I know you say this like 5 is a random number out of millions, but the guess isn't either 1 off or a million miles away, like 5. It's always going to be a very small number out, in a repeating cycle, of only a few numbers. Here is the python code to do the guessing:

def find_factors(a,b):
for tries in range(10):
x = a**tries
y = x/b
if x-(b*y) == 1: print tries, x, y, x-(b*y)

So while your guess might be out, it isn't randomly out. So if you really could do the super-position stuff -- which is what most lay-people are skeptical of -- then you don't need the Fourier transform. You could leave all of that bit out, keeping it simple and still near-instantaneous....?

I have a pet theory that at least one government has an operational quantum computer sufficiently powerful to do this right now. I came to this conclusion while watching documentaries about Blexley Park. Programmable computers were theoretically possible and just beyond the current level of technology of the day (so everyone thought). Little bits and pieces of the fully-functional tech were demonstrable in labs and universities but nobody could actually build one yet... (right?) Well Fowler did build one and it was kept to deathbed-level secrecy.... It wasn't for another 25 years that we learned what had happened.

Quantum computing is in a similar state today that Von Neumann computing was back in the late 1930s.... Ergo it's not unreasonable (I think) to say that top secret government research and funding has likely already advanced the technology to a viable state.

There is one misrepresentation though: By far not all encryption on the Internet is based on the assumption that factoring integers is hard. In fact, reliance on this computational hardness assumption is pretty much exclusive to RSA (though there also exist very rarely used variants of the Schnorr signature scheme that seek to increase their security in this manner).

Most asymmetric schemes used on the Internet are based on the computational hardness assumption regarding calculating discrete logarithms[1], in particular Diffie-Hellman and its elliptic curve derivates.

And symmetric ciphers, which are used to encrypt the bulk of the data, are generally based on neither. Simply put, block ciphers (the most common type) are usually based on combining reversible, simple operations such as XOR, table-based substitution ("S boxes") and bit permutations, and repeatedly applying them for N rounds such that the resulting function becomes mathematically "unapproachable" by any known means.

[1] which however can also be done using Shor's algorithm.

No. The time for a quantum computer that can perform a similar number of operations as, for example, my pc, (which is nowhere close today) can only crack the same key in sqrt of the time my pc would take. So if it takes my PC 1,000,000,000,000 (trillion) operations it would take quantum pc 1,000,000 (million) operations. (half as many zeros) So if both can do 1,000,000 (million) operations in a second, the quantum takes 1 second and my pc takes a million seconds, or 11 days. When making the key stronger, if it adds two zeros to the time for my pc, it adds one zero to the quantum pc so 11 days becomes 1100 (3 something years) and the quantum pc takes 100 seconds or a minute and 40 seconds.

If you have a 2048 bit encryption key let's say it takes 1,000,000 years to crack the key with my PC (just pulling a number out of my ass for time). If you DOUBLE the number of bits to make it a 4096 bit key, it will square the time taken, which so happens to be the ratio of the quantum computer's time. So it would take a quantum PC that's just as fast as my pc the same time to crack a 4096 bit key as it would for my pc to crack a 2048 bit key.

As you can see, all you need to do to make encryption keys strong enough to defend against quantum PC's is double the number of bits used for the key, which is trivial. ALSO quantum computers are NO WHERE CLOSE to being as fast, operations per second-wise, as a normal computer, and it's thought they never will be comparable. Much faster for doing a specific task because it can do it in less steps, but far fewer steps taken in the same period of time.

If I'm not mistaken, not all classical state of the art encryption algorithms use multiplication of large numbers. Elliptic curves, for example, use a similar principle (mathematical operation that is easy to do and hard to undo) and no one has found a quantum algorithm that would effectively break it. So there might be no need to go to quantum encryption, which would require each participant to own a quantum computer, not to mention that it would be essentially impossible to create a network for transmission of quantum states if you are restricted by the no cloning theorem (which severely restricts your ability to enhance a signal on the way).

*THIS ONLY APPLIES TO ASYMMETRIC ENCRYPTION!
There are two basic classes of encryption:
Symmetric encryption is when the key used to encrypt and decrypt are the same. Examples is encrypting a file with a password, and requiring that same password to decrypt.
Asymmetric encryption is when you create a mathematical key pair using prime numbers: one key encrypts the data, but you need the other paired key to decrypt it. This is also called public-key cryptography, since the encryption key is public, but the decryption key is private.
What's the point of asymmetric encryption? It is an essential component of a Diffie-Hellman exchange, which is the most common way for two parties meeting for the first time to establish a shared secret over insecure communications. In other words, it's a method for two people or computers to settle on a password they both know, but making sure no one else knows even if they listened in on the entire conversation. That shared password is then generally used for symmetric encryption of the actual data over that same insecure channel. This video visualizes it in an extremely clever way https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3QnD2c4Xovk
Shor's algorithm lets you find the prime factors used to generate the asymmetric key pair, which use can then be used to recreate the keys. Assuming you listened in on that Diffie-Hellman exchange, you can then find out what secret symmetric key they decided on and decrypt everything they say. Since they entire internet relies on this for secure communication, a man in the middle listening in with a future quantum computer could decipher most of the secrets they hear. But if something (like a file) was encrypted symmetrically with a key that was never shared over a Diffie-Hellman exchange, or if you didn't listen in on that initial exchange, you are pretty SOL unless you find a flaw in the cypher.

Wouldn't that situation likely change the lock on the data from encryption to utilizing the superposition of the data itself meaning if a hacker tries to intercept and read that superposition data it will loose its quantum-ness and therefore resolve to a state that not reliable to the hackers? For instance, using the cat example, if I send quantum data saying the cat is alive but the hackers intercept and open the superposition box then the data will have to pick a state, and if it shows the cat dead the hackers will not know if that is the true answer or not. For complex quantum data the hackers could get an unimaginable amount of possible answers when observing the data thus making any hack untrustworthy or outright gibberish.
Simply explained.

Quantum Computer is an Oxymoron (contradiction in terms). Quantum events, suggest all possibilities exist at the same time, a '0' or '1' exist at the same time. The definition of a Computer is to calculate a result, on STABLE DEFINED inputs. If the inputs have all possible values/states, the output will have all possible/states at the SAME TIME, there would be NO calculation/computation, and no correlation between a particular set of inputs CONNECTED to a particular output. You would need an a INFINITE input array, and a INFINITE output array.
A Quantum Computer is absolute nonsense.
Any Tom, Dick or Harry can build an absolute fool proof encryption algorithm. It is very simple, just distribute each binary BIT of the message, randomly amongst the bytes of a random picture of WHITE NOISE. The encryption key would be the location of each BIT, which would be transmitted/communicated to the recipient using a different channel.

The other benefit to how long it will be before this is a problem is that the more densely we pack the actual electrons to run calculations, the more interference there is with the end data...and no one has figured out a solution to this problem yet.  If your end data is a garbled mess of random interference, it isn't really data.  So current quantum computer implementations utilize vast facilities for relatively little power...right now it's still about the kind of R&D that led to the shrinking of the old IBM room-filling computers into the ones we have today...only quantum computers will probably never end up in sizes that come close to modern laptops, phones, or other such tiny implementations simply because of how much cooling is required to make a single electron stay put.

This is a nice theory to analyze, but in a realistic scenario it's pretty much magical thinking. Practical reality never works the same way as theory especially for very complex things: You can't clap your hands, say "but it's a quantum computer", and boom: Extremely complex and fundamental problems just go away and you can magically break any encryption just because it says "quantum" on it. You still need to find a correspondence to a gigantic random number, which can be generated using any unpredictable formula... meaning you still need to do ridiculous amounts of random guesses. None the less, this might make the task a bit easier unless encryption advances to keep up with the threat.

The title of this video is rather misleading.
Let me explain... just because we might get super fast quantum computers in the future, Internet Security will NOT be destroyed. Why? Simply because of a little thing called "Timeout Delay (TD)" and "Two Factor Authentication (2FA)".
Timeout is an artificially introduced delay in the log-in process, specifically if you enter the first password incorrectly, there'll be a 5 second timeout, and with each subsequent wrong entry the timeout delay may be increases with a predetermined amount or exponentially (similar to the iPhone's screen lock method), therefore rendering any super-fast quantum computer useless. In other words you may be able to generate all the password combinations possible in a short time, but you won't be able to enter it in a short enough time, that is before you die. ;)
Two Factor Authentication takes it a step further, incorporating the Timeout Delay, and it also sends a temporary password/prompt to a second device completely separate from log-in device, and without the proper authentication even the correct password will not work.
Both of these methods can be easily implemented into any website's log-in process, practically nullifying the advantages of the fastest quantum computers on Earth, so Internet Security will NOT be destroyed, to this video maker's dismay! ;D

The way to think about it is like baking a cake, and randomly guessing how much sugar goes in. A normal 'oven' can only bake one cake at a time. A quantum oven can bake a whole bunch of cakes at once. The beauty of the algorithm is that only the non-burnt cakes come out of the oven. And when they do you can look at how sweet they are to figure out if it was the right amount of sugar. It turns out that you can look at the difference in sweetness to figure out the actually correct amount of sugar to put in.

The entire quantum computers break all security premise ignores one fundamental issue.

If computer A (Quantum) runs at infinite speed, and computer B runs at derp, (Normal) computer A will need to SLOW DOWN to interface with computer B, because computer B cannot interface with Computer A at the speeds computer A normally runs at. Computer B simply can't run that fast. Think on this, if you will. What would happen if you tried networking an old tape-based computer from the 50's to a SOTA system circa early 2019?

The "risk" of breaking encryption on the internet is greatly exaggerated. Only RSA and (traditional) Diffie-Hellman rely on (the difficulty of) factorisation. Elliptic-curves, which is not susceptible to factorisation, has been available for years and are widely deployed and used. There are also no known quantum algorithm (or any algorithm) that can efficiently break strong symmetric ciphers like AES. Even for RSA, to break a 2048 bit key, which is the minimum length recommended these days, will require a quantum computer with at least 2048 qbits, which could take decades to develop.

The statement at the beginning that "the encryption of pretty much all private information sent over the internet relies immensely on one numerical phenomenon" is misleading. Prime factorization is only one example of a one-way function and is only the basis of some encryption algorithms (e.g. RSA). Others use an entirely different computationally-hard problem as their basis, for example the discrete logarithm problem which is used in the Diffie-Hellman algorithm - a very widely used key exchange method on the internet.

There is an efficient quantum algorithm for solving the discrete logarithm as well, but they are distinct problems despite some similarities. A more general statement at the beginning about the hidden subgroup problem and the relationship to Shor's algorithm would've been more apt in my opinion.

One thing that I would like to add. Near the beginning you said that encryption was like a lock, we can add more but eventually someone will get through. This is not quite true due to the vast size of the numbers we use and the rate at which the problem complexity grows with respect to the problem size. If we take a look at symmetric encryption (this is for simpler calculations. prime factorization is O(exp(sqrt(nlog^2(n))))) which would lead to less nice numbers but it is similar in spirit), the difficulty of breaking the encryption grows with 2^n where n is the number of bits in the key. This is important because a single bit makes the problem twice as hard. Because of this growth rate, we can extremely easily outpace the computational resources of the entire planet. Even if we took all the energy in all the stars in the observable universe to power computer chips made with every atom in the universe, it would still take longer than the age of the universe to crack AES256 encryption. And if someone starts trying, just add one more bit.

Regular computers use binary which is ONE's for on and ZERO's for off... Quantum computers use 4 stats at the same time.
Which would look like this if it was in binary... ONE +, ONE - , ZERO +, ZERO -, so you would get a combination of multiplication on the work being done. Regular computer is 1+1=2, 2+2=4 etc.... Quantum computer is... (1+1)x(1-1) = (2+)x(2-) at the same time doing double the work. In short binary is a multiple of 2 and quantum computers is like multiple +4 and -4 at the same time.
OR
The best way to explain it is to compare it to options trading on the stock market.

Binary= Spend $$$ buy stock... or Sell Stock Collect $$$.
Options trading= Buy call option to make money when the stock goes up. or Sell call option to make money when stock goes down.
Options trading= Buy put option to make money when stock goes down. or Sell put option to make money when stock goes up.

You get four choices to make money on options and only two choices on stocks.
Quantum computer 4 vs Regular computer 2.

To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand quantum computing. It might be fun to note that quantum computing won't necessarily compromise your passwords and other encrypted traffic.
Because first of all; the moment quantum computing technology becomes available it would be very cost ineffecient to just set about brute-forcing random encrypted traffic. It will thus only be usable by a government or university. Who generally aren't that interested in your personal data. (Though this could depend on the government in question).
It'll probably take a while before running tasks on a quantum computer becomes available for public use.
Secondly; encryption using factorisation of numbers is already a rather dated method and better encryption algorithms already exist and are more widely used on modern platforms.
It would only pose problems for old websites who haven't updated their encryption methods and websites who are just too lazy to be bothered with it. Though these websites do still exist in plentiful amounts.

It should have been said that making a quantum computer of size 2x costs more than 2x to make, so even if we need machines a thousand times larger to break current keys, it doesn't take a mere thousand times as many resources to build it.  It takes much much ... much much more.  Hearding 4 of Schroedinger's cats at once is more than twice the challenge of hearding 2 of his cats.  The encryptors may be able to perpetually stay ahead of the decryptors as long as they keep current with key length.

This is why botnets scare me. Heres the thing, it took 2000 years of computer processing time. Given that almost every person in the US have a laptop, and it's a fair guess that at least half arent safe in their computer usage and are thus susceptible to becoming part of a botnet, you're talking about 160 million processors. And in a botnet of that size, you're looking at about a half hour to reach two thousand years of cpu time. That also assumes every computer in the net is single core and that's a bad assumption. The vast majority of computers have 4 logical processors. So no were talking 15 minutes for a botnet half that size. Distributed computing is what I'm worried about not quantum computers since, you know, quantum computers are just an idea, where botnets with over a million logical processors in them currently exist.

1. The most widely used encryption that is affected by this problem is RSA, an asymmetric encryption that is only used for specific tasks, because it requires a lot of computational power.

3. There are already alternatives to RSA in the making.
4. For most encryptions that don't use the sum of to big numbers quantum computers only double the amount power you have. So doubling the key length is enough.

There's a lot more protections built into more advanced encryption algorithms which makes the usefulness of quantum computing to be much less than seen in the video.
You may be able to "break" a single digit, but with the cypher being regenerated each pass, you end up having a problem of getting not just a single digit pair which can represent a salt value (for example), you still need to figure out the password to decrypt the actual message.
If someone uses a password that is 128 bits long, the numbers become so great that the computation time using quantum computers will take close to a million years for a single quantum computer. That's because the total number of entangled particles is still relatively small (about 1000 entangled particles in a chip).

Tl;dr
Modern encryptions would still take up unreasonably long periods of time even for a quantum computer to break.

So the only private keys you can decrypt are empty wallets.

Hey really great video. I'll be starting my PhD in computer science next semester working on (among other things) post-quantum cryptography, that is, crypto that is based on problems that (we think at least) are hard for quantum computers to do as well. Lattice crypto (problems whose security is based on the apparent hardness of some lattice problems) is a major player here, while also providing tons of advantages over current crypto (like making fully homomorphic encryption possible which I'm really excited about). So I'm mainly just commenting to say all is not lost! As you said, we have some time before quantum computers become a serious threat.

Secondly, I wanted to add that quantum computers (and indeed Shor's algorithm) not only break RSA by efficiently factoring large integers but also one of the other big asymmetric players: the Diffie Hellman key exchange, which is based on the apparent hardness, for classical computers anyway, of solving the discrete log problem (basically given g, p and x, it's hard to find a y such that g^y = x (mod p)).

Symmetric encryption, to my knowledge, seems to be somewhat safe. The biggest name in this field, AES, (with sufficiently large key sizes) still appears to be secure against quantum attacks.

Anyway great video. Super clear explanation of Shor's algorithm!

Edit: oh one other interesting thing. You mentioned in your video that encryption doesn't make it impossible to access the underlying data, just more difficult. This is true for most encryption, but there does exist "information-theoretically secure" encryption which is literally for all intents and purposes unbreakable. However it is impractical in most use cases. The quintisential example here are one-time-pads (OTP). They require that both parties must start out with the same secret information (the pad) with which they encrypt/decrypt their message like any symmetric encryption scheme (already presenting some difficulty), but even worse the pad must be as long as the message itself and the pad can only be used once as the name suggests (this isn't just a weakness of OTPs though it is mathematically proven that all information-theoretically secure encryption schemes have similar disadvantages). One time pads are still used when absolute security is necessary though. During WWII phone calls between FDR and Winston Churchill were encrypted via OTPs. In order for both FDR and Churchill to end up with the same pad, armed soldiers would handcuf briefcases full of these pads to themselves and literally fly across the Atlantic to transport them.

Awesome video! However the very last sentence "No need to worry about encryption just yet" isn't exactly true. Recorded traffic could be broken in the future, revealing secrets that might still be relevant then. Think a journalist that uses encryption to stay anonymous but is still working in a dangerous country 10 years from now. Worrying about encryption that can be calculated on classical computers but is safe from classical AND quantum computers is something that has to be done now.

Well Shor's algorithm on quantum computers doesn't "break encryption", but just some commonly used public encryption ciphers, like RSA (the one you took as example), DH or ECC, which are only used for key exchange. Everything else remains secure, including all symmetric (eg AES), as well as the asymmetric PQC-ciphers, not talking of the OTP.
This means the moment Shor's algorithm becomes applicable on quantum computers (so the moment quantum computers turn into reality), there will be a simple update with a change of protocol within the browsers and openssl and that's it. No "breaking the internet", sorry. That's fear mongering.
Afaik, Chrome already includes Google's "A New Hope"-PQC cipher (which has been entered as contestant along 20 or so others for standardization in NISTs PQC contest)

so every prime number larger than 3 can be expressed as 6n+1 or 6n-1 - which means the product of two prime numbers will be equal to one of four equations, (6a+1)*(6b+1), (6a+1)*(6b-1), (6a-1)*(6b+1) or (6a-1)*(6b-1) where a and b are whole integers. To find the prime divisors you would need to solve for each of those where mod a (and/or mod b) is 0 (e.g. if (6a+1)*(6b+1) = <big number here> mod a = 0 then you can work out both your prime divisors). wolfram alpha can solve this for decently sized numbers fairly quickly, I know because I tried. solving a 2048 bit number might be slightly more difficult but you could plot each equation for any arbitrary number and there should only be one or two integer solutions.

This can never "break" encryption. All it does is just brute force the problem faster. But a property of these kind of problems is that, if you increase the "difficulty" (in this case make the number bigger) the needed effort to solve it brute-force will increase EXPONENTIALLY i.e. if we would simply make the number a handful of digits larger, the effort would already explode into scales, where quantum computers won't be able to solve it anymore due to being slow or lacking the memory. Simply increasing the number by some digits takes almost no extra effort. I.e. it's very easy to increase the required effort of "breaking" encryption by orders of magnitude.


Unless we will be able to increase memory / processing power of these quantum computers EXPONENTIALLY ON A WHIM, encryption schemes can simply just use more digits and they will always be enough safe.


The actual "real way" to break encryption would be to prove "P = NP" (these are not the P's from the video). But this is an entirely different topic of cryptography.


If any of those 2 cases would be possible some time in the future, the whole world would break and enter a new era of technology.

Few important corrections:
1. The digital security world has been turning away from integer-factoring-based security for decades now. If you magically get that factoring here and now, you'll be surprised how little of the internet you would actually "break".

Details. Integer factorization doesn't in any way help break AES, which is the common algo for symmetric encryption and how you would normally store encrypted data. RSA is asymmetric. Would you be able to snoop into the handshake part of https? (in hopes to get the symmetric key and decrypt the passwords in a login request) Nope, that uses Diffie-Hellman, based on complexity of the discrete logarithm, not integer factorization. Ok, well, maybe key signatures? Not to snoop in directly, but to make MitM attack (which requires infrastructure control, but let's pretend to ignore that). Nope, ECDSA is now used more often there. No cigar.

2. at 0:35 you correctly name Number Field Sieve as the best approach we currently have for integer factorization, but then on 1:30 you show & explain brute force guessing as "the current best method" which in no way relates to (G)NFS. Even though you write a^2-b^2 in the end as a "clever trick", that's still not a good presentation of the situation.

For example there is also AES which due to its properties is actually already quite quantum resistant (there is an attack that effectively halves the key size but doubling the keysize is easy and means quantum computers will still take decades to break AES keys), the disadvantage of AES is that it is a private key only encryption scheme so it is mostly useful for data at rest (HD encryption) or after some kind of handshake that might involve RSA (which is what happens in the Internet)

It's claimed the strongest classical encryption available now (with perfect forward secrecy) is resistant to decryption by quantum computers in any reasonable period of time.

Also to be clear: Shor's algorithm only factors integers (or solves the related problem of finding logarithms of integers behind a modulus). That definitely spells doom for RSA (which draws its strength from the classical difficulty of these two problems), but Shor's is not a magic bullet against all encryption - the private-key algorithms (that is, those where the same key/password is used for both encrypting and decrypting, like what you'd use to encrypt your laptop) tend not to rely on any kind of "I can compute N = p x q but you can't recover p and q from N" asymmetry to work properly.


Even as public-key/asymmetric encryption goes, these days RSA is actually losing a lot of its popularity to the so-called "elliptic curve" algorithms, which use a very different sort of "mathematical one-way trapdoor" to work - they operate using points on a curve, no "factors of integers" involved. Shor's is useless against those! (And with any luck, RSA and co. should be completely abandoned by the time quantum computers catch up.)

you are grossly oversimplifying the way encryption works. most standard encryption standards don't use simple math to encode information, they use advanced and multi-layered  substitution and permutation ciphers. they keys to which are created with some pretty extreme randomized information (see the infamous wall of lava lamps cloud flare uses and the atmospheric microphones from random.org) in a general sense they use some secret algorithm to turn the random inputs into data, and that functions as the key, then its put through the substitution and permutation cipher to scramble the information. without knowing the key being used, its practically impossible to decode the information. now obviously there are ways and thats why we are continually improving our encryption methods.  Having said that, the idea you are presenting is still fairly viable as far as using quantum computing to try and "crack the code" I am by no means and expert on either the encryption process or in the logic behind code breaking in this sense however, and I cannot say how this shor's algorithm would work on a traditional AES encryption standard. so assuming that it would work and your core message of "this simple(ish) algorithm used on a quantum computer could more easily and quickly break encryption" is still correct, this video is still a disservice to your viewers and woefully misleading.

Quantum computing does not break encryption. It breaks a select subset of encryption algorithms, primarily used for key-exchange. AES, the algorithm currently used to encrypt almost all data on the internet, is already resistant against Shor's algorithm. And quantum-safe ways for key-exchange are also readily available.

quantum cryptography already exists(unlike any kind of reliable quantum computer that can actually break shors algorithm) and with quantum cryptography we can be sure that encryption is not in any kind of danger because no quantum computer can break quantum cryptographic encryption. but just for the sake of argument, lets say something could break QC, you would know that someone broke the encryption. so no need for anyone to be worried about the click bait title here. the future of encryption is safe and we already have it.

More fun things about RSA:

If you want to know how the RSA algorithm works specifically here is a MIT lecture https://youtu.be/q1OF_0ICt9A

When calculating the 2 prime numbers that we will use for encryption instead of checking if it is actuality prime we will run a algorithm to see if it is 99.999999...% probably prime. This is because the algorithm to actually check would take forever and ironically it would be less likely to be correct because the about of time it would take means that it would be probable for bits to get flipped from radiation

When you use RSA to encrypt stuff you don't actual use RSA. Instead you use RSA to encrypt a different key (usually AES). We do this because RSA can only encrypt a specific amount of information proportional to the side of the primes used to make its keys. This makes encrypting with pure RSA RAM and CPU intensive.

RSA can also be used to sign data. This means if I have a key and some data you can see if I put a signature on the
data with out knowing what the key was.

The internet generally uses keys that are 2^11 or 2^12 bits long.

One 2^11 bit long key was cracked a few years ago by a super computer cluster working for 4 years

If you make a key lineally longer it will take lineally longer to encrypt/decrypt data but it will take exponentially longer to crack it.
